Easy answer but please focus on what I will say and avoid prejudiced “knowledge” you may already have and it is wrong. Ancient Macedonia was 100% Greece* and did not include the nowadays North Macedonia (it is already agreed with North Macedonia that Macedonia in Greece belongs to Greek culture from ancient times until today). Macedonians of Ancient Greece, have controlled the surrounding northern areas, but have never been inhabited by Macedonians (Greeks); they were only controlled so to protect (ancient) Macedonia from invasions from North. In Roman and Ottoman Empires, the North of (ancient) Macedonia had started being developed and inhabited by Greeks, Romans (after the Roman invasion to Greece), Slavs after the 6th century (the Byzantine period), Goths, and the Turks in the 14th century. During this period, both the Romans and the Ottomans have re-organized administrative the area according to their needs. The Slavs have started being a significant part of the population in all this area, including Macedonia for the additional reason that Macedonians (Greeks) had been fighting either in all Asia and North Africa, not only with the Greeks with Alexander, and his successors but also with the Byzantine Empire against Persians, Arabs, and Turks. In the same period, the Slavs have for long periods organized as Bulgarians and the whole Macedonia had been part of the Bulgarian kingdom during the Byzantine period, manned by those Slavs living in Macedonia and North Macedonia. So in the period before the liberation of the area from the Ottoman Empire, Bulgaria has raised the case of this area without any relation with whatever Macedonia, but only because Bulgaria tried to justify its national interest to include these lands with Slavic (Bulgarian according to Bulgaria) speaking populations, both Ancient Macedonia area and nowadays North Macedonia {which North, as explained above, was not inhabited by Macedonians(Greeks) in ancient times, but only after the Roman conquest}. After Greece had liberated Macedonia (not North Macedonia that was liberated by the Serbs) from the Ottoman Empire, there was a period of free exchange of Christian populations between the borders of respective countries (Greece and Serbia) which lasted until the cold war; therefore those Slavs of Macedonia (Greece) feeling Serbs moved to Serbia (nowadays North Macedonia) and those Slavs feeling Bulgarians moved to Bulgaria, while with the reverse direction feeling Greeks from Serbia (North Macedonia) or Bulgaria moved to Macedonia (Greece as Macedonia from ancient times). Conclusion those living in North Macedonia have never been anything else than Slavs and have no relation with ancient Macedonia.
